#Text=4 .
#Text=Performance Evaluation of Energy Conservation Technologies and WWTPs
#Text=Before introducing the evaluation methods and indicators , we use a table to summarize the main energy-saving technologies mentioned in this paper .
#Text=These technologies include green energy technologies and optimization technologies , it is difficult to evaluate them with a unified indicator , so we will explain them in the form of cases .
#Text=Table 6 shows some common energy-saving technologies and their energy efficiency performance .
#Text=Many factors , such as processes , scale , water quality , have a great impact on energy consumption , which has been explained in Section 1.2.2 .
#Text=This review introduces a variety of energy-saving technologies from the aspects of energy supply and system optimization in Section 2 and Section 3 .
#Text=Therefore , some indexes and methods are needed to evaluate the application value and comprehensive performance of these energy conservation technologies .
#Text=4.1 .
#Text=Evaluation
#Text=Indexes

#Text=The appropriate evaluation index can not only evaluate energy the performance of WWTPs horizontally but also evaluates the differences of processes vertically , which can provide guidance for technological improvement .
#Text=Besides , it can help researchers confirm the application value of energy conservation technologies .
#Text=The diversity of energy-saving technologies makes some indexes that can comprehensively compare their differences more valuable .
#Text=In Section 1.2.1 , EI is used to describe energy performance .
#Text=Energy consumption per volume of treated wastewater and energy consumption per unit of pollutant removal are two widely used energy indexes , both of which have some problems .

#Text=Energy consumption per unit of pollutant removal needs to consider a variety of pollutants , which will cause difficulties , while energy consumption per volume of treated wastewater ignores the difference of wastewater ( water quality , scale , process , etc. ) .
#Text=This problem has been described in Section 1.2.1 .

#Text=The premise of using energy consumption per volume of treated wastewater is that the fluctuation of influent water quantity and water quality ( COD , BOD , SS , TN , and TP , etc. ) of sewage treatment plants is relatively small , and the situation of influent water quality and water quantity of each sewage treatment plant is comparatively close .
#Text=In general , energy conservation technology needs to consider energy , feasibility , treatment capacity , economy , environment , policy , water supply safety , risk , and other factors .
#Text=This is also the premise of energy-saving applications such as multi-objective optimization and optimal control .
#Text=There are various performance evaluation indexes for WWTPs .
#Text=Table 7 shows the indexes used by some researchers .
#Text=These different indexes with different concerns can show the various situations of WWTPs .
#Text=This makes the data on energy performance , application value and popularization potential of energy-saving technology more reliable .
#Text=However , many researchers pay attention to a unit but do not set indexes from the whole life cycle , which makes indexes not comprehensive .
#Text=It is not a good choice , because the indexes have a great impact on the audit results of WWTPs .
#Text=To establish a unified analysis method for energy consumption in WWTPs , the ENERWATER project was launched in Europe to conduct index studies on WWTPs .

#Text=Water treatment energy index ( WTEI ) , a comprehensive index formed by weighting and a combination of multiple indexes , is used to evaluate the energy efficiency of WWTPs in the ENERWATER framework .
#Text=After confirming the type of WWTP , indexes are constructed according to the data of energy consumption , pollutant concentration , and flow rate .
#Text=4.2 .
#Text=Evaluation Methods

#Text=Appropriate evaluation methods can help managers to understand the energy utilization of the entire process through various data of the wastewater treatment plant , and to find opportunities for energy efficiency optimization .

#Text=Only when the above objectives are achieved , can the results of energy research and technical analysis be used to guide technological transformation and engineering practice . Stefano Longo et al. study three benchmark methods : normative method , statistical method , and programming method , and conducted energy efficiency evaluation .
#Text=The Key Performance Indicators ( KPIs ) method is the most common and simplest evaluation method .
#Text=KPIs , the most commonly used evaluation method in WWTPs , is usually expressed as the ratio of output to input .
#Text=The KPIs method is simple and easy to implement , but it can only evaluate specific parts , and it cannot systematically evaluate the status of WWTPs .
#Text=Although the KPIs can be created by weighting , the complexity of the WWTPs process makes the method unsuitable .
#Text=Similarly , the KPIs method ignores the differences in WWTPs ( location , size , process ) .
#Text=Data Envelopment Analysis ( DEA ) is a tool using mathematical programming technology for performance evaluation .
#Text=It can be used to evaluate energy performance in complex systems such as wastewater treatment because it can deal with multiple inputs and outputs problems .
#Text=The BCC model and the CCR ratio model are two types of DEA models .

#Text=The CCR model can evaluate the overall efficiency of a unit while the BCC model evaluates the pure technical efficiency of a unit . Guerrini et al. used DEA to study the relationship between sewage characteristics and energy efficiency .
#Text=They gave some suggestions for efficient operation .
